message: and yea, i like mercurial too (used on sourceforge), but you get my point..

now, i know the overall benefits of git over svn, not to say svn isnt awesome (youve all used and once loved it).  but for some nostalgic reason, i keep some of my older projects on source-forge and am finally debating switching it all over..

I would switch them for 1. mental burden of having to remember "is X on github, or ...?" 2. github is a less heavy weight system than sourceforge iirc, and 3. you are more likely to get attention/contributions on github.
I say switch (and I should do the same) because you get a lot more exposure on github. It's social coding after all, and sourceforge is more like anti-social coding.
I say switch (and I should do the same) because you get a lot more exposure on github. It's social coding after all, and sourceforge is more like anti-social coding.
...but its UI and community is much better.

Yea, i'd have to agree, it seems its far more likely to get contributors and exposure on github, and githubs interface is really nice.  thanks for the thoughts.   it makes sense, though whats kinda funny/sad is when someone random asked me about my github account, and i mentioned source-forge, (i had to then explain what source forge was). heh
and i have to add its been very easy to spin up repos in github, theyve def given the UX some thought.
So why are you asking for opinions?  You seem to know enough to say "I don't like SourceForge, GitHub looks better."

GitHub is a tool, much like SourceForge was.  I would say GitHub is a better tool, but unless you feel your projects are lacking in something (visibility, ability to contribute, etc.) and you think GitHub can do that, there's no reason to switch.

@klauern, Why ask, cause what i know (or what i think i know might be wrong), though id get other perspectives and what not.  And i'd agree with your last comment as well, which is why im moving some repos over.  it was more, i didnt want to miss something really obvious.
